blog.title: Daleke 1914. započeo je I. svjetski rat atentatom na austrougarskog nadvojvodu Franza (Franju) Ferdinanda u Sarajevu.

blog_graphql.naslovBlogaEng: The First World War started back in the 1914 with the assassination of Franz Ferdinand in Sarajevo.
blog_graphql.naslovBlogaHr: Daleke 1914. započeo je I. svjetski rat atentatom na Franza (Franju) Ferdinanda u Sarajevu
blog_graphql.tekstBlogaEng:
The First World War started back in the 1914 with the assassination of the Austrian Hungarian archduke Franz Ferdinand in Sarajevo. This event made the small Dalmatian town Metković the centre of the world because it was the place where the archduke spent his last days of life and also sent off the archduke’s body on its last resting place in Vienna.

The trail of the archduke’s journey to Sarajevo went through Metković, where his arrival was photographed by the Metković’s photographer Nikolac. Nikolac couldn’t even guess that several days later, on the railway station in Metković, he would await the archduke and his wife in their coffins. It was then that several more photographs were made, which showed paying the last honors to the deceased and boarding the coffins of Franz Ferdinand and his wife Sofia Chotek to the yacht Dalmat. Several weeks later, Nikolac printed 10 of his best photographs as postcards (in the form of a convenient block), wanting to mark this event. Today this block is one of the most elite series of Dalmatian postcards, due to its multiple historical and documentary meaning, but also a small circulation, and it is therefore very rare and wanted among postcard collectors, while only two copies are known to be kept in its original form. The postcards from this series were first published in Croatia in the monographs from the series Forgotten Dalmatia.

And the event itself – how did the assassination in Sarajevo happen?

Franz Ferdinand set on his journey off to Sarajevo from Vienna, on June 23rd 1914, on a special train to Trieste. After that he sailed on the military ship SMS Viribus Unitis to the mouth of Neretva, in order to board there the yacht Dalmat (later known as Istranka), which took him all the way to Metković, where there was a solemn reception for him. In Metković there was a special train which set off towards Sarajevo. Franz Ferdinand arrived on June 25th to Sarajevo, where he and his wife Sofia checked into the hotel Bosnia on Ilidža. The Franz Ferdinand’s security was minimal and there were less than 120 police officers in charge of his security. Sofia was thrilled with the reception in Sarajevo. She came to Sarajevo on a train through Budapest and Slavonski Brod, and on every station there was a solemn reception.  While Franz Ferdinand was busy with his political duties, Sofia was visiting the Sarajevo schools, churches and humanitarian institutions.

According to the official plan, from 28th June 1914, Franz Ferdinand was suppose to pay an official visit to Sarajevo before noon, and in the afternoon he was supposed to leave the town and return home through Metković, embarking on a ship. The entire plan of his visit, with exact places which the procession was to pass through, was published a day earlier in the Bosanska pošta. Having learned the procession’s route, the assassinators, members of the terrorist organization “Mlada Bosna” (Young Bosnia) were divided and set on several locations along the route. The goal of this organization was to throw off the Austrian Hungarian authorities in Bosnia and Herzegovina through rebellions and armed assassinations.

Having survived the first attempt of an attack with a hand grenade earlier that morning, the archduke went on with his protocol, arriving to the city Hall where he was supposed to listen to the complimentary speech. But before the complimentary speech, he excitedly criticized the Sarajevo mayor, Fehrim Čurčić, saying: “Mister mayor, I have come here to visit you, and they are throwing bombs at me. This is outrageous.” It was only after countess Sofia whispered something in his ear, that Franz Ferdinand calmed down somewhat and allowed mayor Čurčić to continue with his speech. After the speech the officials and members of the Franz Ferdinand’s entourage discussed what should they do. Finally, Franz Ferdinand and Sofia gave up on the official plan and decided to visit the victims of the bomb attack.

When heading to the hospital the driver started off the wrong way, so he had to stop and go back. It is that exact moment that the assassinator Gavrilo Princip used to shoot, hitting thus both Franz and Sofia, who both passed away shortly after. How shocking and unbelievable for everyone present! The assassinators were caught right away and soon condemned.

The bodies of Franz Ferdinand and Sofia were in the end transferred to Metković on 30th June 1914, embarked on the yacht Dalmat which took them to SMS Viribus Unitis, in Trieste, and later back to Vienna. Everything that followed was well known and recorded in the world history. No one could have even imagined that this event would mark the beginning of the First World War and a million of dead people.

 

Igor Goleš
blog_graphql.tekstBlogaHr:
Daleke 1914. započeo je I. svjetski rat atentatom na austrougarskog nadvojvodu Franza (Franju) Ferdinanda u Sarajevu. Ovaj događaj  učinio je na trenutak maleni dalmatinski gradić Metković centrom svijeta jer je svjedočio posljednjim danima života prijestolonasljednika, ali ga i nedugo potom mrtvog ispratio na posljednje počivalište u Beč.

Trasa njegovog putovanja za Sarajevo vodila  je upravo preko Metkovića gdje je njegov  dolazak fotografirao metkovski fotograf Jure Nikolac koji nije mogao ni slutiti da će par dana nakon tog dana  dočekati  nadvojvodu i njegovu suprugu na željezničkoj stanici u Metkoviću u mrtvačkim kovčezima. Tada nastaje još nekoliko fotografija koje prikazuju posljednju počast te ukrcaj ljesova Franza Ferdinanda i njegove supruge Sofije Chotek na brod Dalmat. Nikolac je nekoliko tjedana kasnije, 10 najboljih fotografija tiskao kao razglednice (u formi prigodnog  bloka) čime je htio obilježiti  ovaj događaj.  Danas je taj blok jedna od najelitnijih serija dalmatinskih razglednica zbog višestrukog povijesnog i dokumentarnog značaja i male tiraže, te je vrlo  rijedak i tražen među kolekcionarima razglednica, a zna se za samo dva sačuvana kompleta u izvornom obliku. Razglednice iz ove serije  prvi put u Hrvatskoj objavljene su u monografijama iz serijala Zaboravljena Dalmacija.

A sam događaj?  Kako je došlo do atentata u Sarajevu?

Franjo Ferdinand krenuo je iz Beča za Sarajevo 23. lipnja 1914. godine, posebnim vlakom do Trsta. Potom je vojnim brodom SMS Viribus Unitis doplovio do ušća Neretve, da bi se onda ukrcao na jahtu Dalmat (kasnije znana kao Istranka) kojom je doplovio do Metkovića gdje mu je bio pripremljen svečani doček. U Metkoviću ga je dočekao posebni vlak kojim je krenu za Sarajevo u koje je doputovao 25. lipnja te je sa suprugom Sofijom odsjeo u hotelu Bosna na Ilidži. Osiguranje Franje Ferdinda u Sarajevu bilo je minimalno, oko 120 policijskih službenika zaduženih za njegovu sigurnost.  Sofija je bila oduševljena dočekom u Sarajevu. Ona je putovala vlakom preko Budimpešte i Slavonskog Broda, te joj je na svim stanicama bio priređen svečani doček. Dok je nadvojvoda bio zauzet državničkim dužnostima, Sofija je posjećivala sarajevske škole, crkve i dobrotvorne ustanove.

Po službenom planu, od 28. lipnja 1914., Franjo Ferdinand je trebao službeno posjetiti Sarajevo prijepodne, a poslijepodne je već trebao napustiti grad i vratit se preko Metkovića brodom kući. Cjelokupan program njegovog posjeta, s točnim mjestima koja će povorka obići,  dan ranije je objavio list Bosanska pošta. Saznavši rutu povorke, atentatori, pripadnici terorističke organizacije Mlada Bosna raspodijelili su se na nekoliko lokacija. Cilj ove tajne organizacije bio je pobunama i  atentatima zbaciti austrougarsku vlast u Bosni i Hercegovini.

Iako je prvi pokušaj napada ručnom bombom to jutro nadvojvoda preživio, ipak je nastavio s protokolom došavši do gradske vijećnice gdje je trebao poslušati pozdravni govor. No, uzbuđeno je kritizirao gradonačelnika Sarajeva  Fehrima Čurčića izjavivši: Gospodine gradonačelniče, došao sam ovdje u posjet, a na mene bacaju bombe. To je nečuveno. Tek nakon što mu je grofica Sofija prišapnula nešto u uho, Franjo Ferdinand se donekle smirio i dopustio gradonačelniku Čurčiću nastaviti s govorom. Službenici i pripadnici pratnje prijestolonasljednika nakon govora su raspravljali što dalje učiniti. Franjo Ferdinand i Sofija naposljetku su odustali od službenog plana i odlučili da će u bolnici posjetiti žrtve bombaškog napada.

Na putu prema bolnici vozač je pogriješio te morao zastati i krenuti unatrag. Upravo taj trenutak iskoristio je atentator Gavrilo Princip zapucavši te pritom pogodivši i Franza i Sofiju koji su nedugo nakon toga preminuli. Kakav šok i nevjerica za sve prisutne. Atentatori su odmah uhvaćeni i ubrzo osuđeni.

Tijela Franje Ferdinanda i Sofije 30. lipnja 1914. su vlakom prenesena do Metkovića, ukrcana na jahtu Dalmat koja ih je Neretvom prevezla do ušća gdje su prenesena na SMS Viribus Unitis, do Trsta, a potom i natrag do Beča. Sve što je uslijedilo, dobro je poznato u svjetskoj povijesti, nitko nije mogao  ni slutiti da će ovaj događaj dovesti do početka I. svjetskog rata i milijuna mrtvih.

 

Igor Goleš
